awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alexandra M. Florea is "Moments and Zeros in Families of L-Functions." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Bristol (U.K.), and the sponsoring scientist is Jonathan Keating.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship, 
the PI studied questions about L-functions in the function field setting. The 
fellowship resulted in eight publications, one of which was submitted after the end 
date of the award. More specifically, the PI focused on computing moments in 
various families of L-functions, with applications to various non-vanishing results 
and questions about ranks of elliptic curves. In joint work with C. David and M. Lalin, 
the PI proved that a positive proportion of L-functions associated to cubic characters in 
the function field setting do not vanish at the central point 1/2. Previously, no positive 
proportion result was known for this family of L-functions, either in the number field or 
function field setting (not even conditionally). This result partially built on previous 
work of the PI with the same co-authors on moments of cubic L-functions over function 
fields, which was also performed during the award period. In joint work with H. Bui, 
J. Keating and E. Roditty-Gershon, the PI studied the family of quadratic twists of 
elliptic curve L-functions over function fields, and obtained several asymptotic formulas 
for moments involving the L-functions of quadratic twists and their derivatives. This 
result gave lower bounds on the correlations between the analytic ranks of the twists 
of two distinct elliptic curves.


While supported by DMS-1703695, the PI has been active in making her work available 
and understandable to undergraduate and graduate students, by giving several general 
audience talks. The PI has also been a mentor to two female undergraduates through 
the AWM Mentorship program.

Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Alexandra M Florea
por.por_txt_cntn:
During the course of this Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship, the PI studied questions about L-functions in the function field setting. The fellowship resulted in eight publications, one of which was submitted after the end date of the award. More specifically, the PI focused on computing moments in various families of L-functions, with applications to various non-vanishing results and questions about ranks of elliptic curves. In joint work with C. David and M. Lalin, the PI proved that a positive proportion of L-functions associated to cubic characters in the function field setting do not vanish at the central point 1/2. Previously, no positive proportion result was known for this family of L-functions, either in the number field or function field setting (not even conditionally). This result partially built on previous work of the PI with the same co-authors on moments of cubic L-functions over function fields, which was also performed during the award period. In joint work with H. Bui, J. Keating and E. Roditty-Gershon, the PI studied the family of quadratic twists of elliptic curve L-functions over function fields, and obtained several asymptotic formulas for moments involving the L-functions of quadratic twists and their derivatives. This result gave lower bounds on the correlations between the analytic ranks of the twists of two distinct elliptic curves.
While supported by DMS-1703695, the PI has been active in making her work available and understandable to undergraduate and graduate students, by giving several general audience talks. The PI has also been a mentor to two female undergraduates through the AWM Mentorship program.
